PERSONA:
meet michael johnson, a 38-year-old married white man residing in a metropolitan area of new england. born and raised in boston, massachusetts, he comes from a devoutly catholic family and still identifies with the faith, though he seldom attends religious services these days.

michael didn't complete a college degree, but he did attend some years of community college before entering the workforce. he now works as an operations supervisor at a medium-sized manufacturing plant on the outskirts of boston, earning a middle-class family income between $90,000 and $100,000 per year. his wife sarah is a registered nurse, and together they are raising two young children, ages 8 and 5.

the johnsons own a modest three-bedroom home in a working-class suburb of boston. with a mortgage, child expenses, and the high cost of living in the area, their income is relatively comfortable but leaves little room for extras. michael is fiscally conservative, prioritizing financial responsibility and opposing tax increases that could strain their household budget further.

though he uses the internet frequently for work and keeping up with news, michael doesn't have much time for volunteerism beyond occasional community events through his local church. his political views lean conservative republican, shaped by his upbringing, catholic values emphasizing traditional family structures, and economic situation as a middle-income homeowner concerned about taxes and the costs of living.

on social issues, michael tends to hold somewhat conservative positions influenced by his religious background, though he is relatively moderate compared to the party's farther-right wing. he supported trump in 2016 and 2020, primarily due to economic reasons, though he has grown disillusioned with the republican party's inflammatory rhetoric at times.

overall, michael is a middle-class family man motivated by economic practicality, religious values, and a desire for stability and security for his household. while he still generally identifies as a conservative republican, he is open to centrist policies from either party that could benefit middle-income families like his own.
